article.title: Advance_Australia_Fair
article.paragraph: Use Australian EnglishApril 2012Infobox anthemAdvance Australia Fair National anthem booth - floriade.jpg The "Australia Fair Grand Concert Street Organ", which automatically plays "Advance Australia Fair" National [[Australia]] [[Peter Dodds McCormick]] 1878 Peter Dodds McCormick 1878 1984 U.S. Navy Band, Advance Australia Fair (instrumental).ogg Advance Australia Fair (Instrumental) "Advance Australia Fair" is thenational anthemofAustralia. Created by the Scottish-born composerPeter Dodds McCormick, the song was first performed in 1878, and was sung in Australia as a patriotic song. It replaced "God Save the Queen". It did not gain its status as the official anthem until 1984, following aAustralian plebiscite, 1977plebiscite to choose the national song in 1977. Other songs and marches have been influenced by "Advance Australia Fair", such as the Australian vice-regal salute.
article.heading: History
Origin
article.paragraph: "Advance Australia Fair" was composed in the late 19th century byPeter Dodds McCormickunder the pen-name "Amicus" (which means "friend" in Latin). It was first performed byAndrew Fairfaxat aHighland Society (Australia)Highland Societyfunction in Sydney on 30 November 1878. The song quickly gained popularity and an amended version was sung by a choir of around 10,000 at the inauguration of theCommonwealth of Australiaon 1 January 1901. In 1907 the Australian Government awarded McCormick 100 for his composition.
In a letter to R.B. Fuller, dated 1 August 1913, McCormick described the circumstances that inspired him to write "Advance Australia Fair":

paragraph.template: quote<arg name="One night I attended a great concert in the Exhibition Building, when all the National Anthems of the world were to be sung by a large choir with band accompaniment. This was very nicely done, but I felt very aggravated that there was not one note for Australia. On the way home in a bus, I concocted the first verse of my song & when I got home I set it to music. I first wrote it in the Tonic Sol-fa notation, then transcribed it into the Old Notation, & I tried it over on an instrument next morning, & found it correct. Strange to say there has not been a note of it altered since. Some alteration has been made in the wording, but the sense is the same. It seemed to me to be like an inspiration, & I wrote the words & music with the greatest ease.{{cite web|url">http://nla.gov.au/anbd.bib-an000008257145|title

article.paragraph: The earliest known sound recording of "Advance Australia Fair" appears inThe Landing of the Australian Troops in Egypt(circa 1916), a short commercial recording dramatising the arrival of Australian troops in Egypten routeto Gallipoli.The Landing of the Australian Troops in Egyptfrom National Film and Sound Archive, at australianscreen online

Before its adoption as Australia's national anthem, "Advance Australia Fair" had considerable use elsewhere. For example, Australia's national broadcaster, theAustralian Broadcasting CorporationAustralian Broadcasting Commission, used it to announce its news bulletins until 1952.cite webhttp://www.screensound.gov.au/services/soa-media/index.htmlMedia Resources – Images and Audio files for Download[[National Film and Sound Archive]]1 November 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20071018045853/http://screensound.gov.au/services/soa-media/index.html18 October 2007(1943 The Majestic Fanfare by Charles Williams, the ABC radio news theme)It was also frequently played at the start or end of official functions. Towards the end of World War II it was played in picture theatres after "God Save the King" and theStar Spangled BannerAmerican national anthem."Song and Two Anthems" ''Sydney Morning Herald'' 30 November 1943 p.4
article.heading: Competitions, plebiscite and adoption
article.paragraph: In 1951 there was a competition for a new national anthem to celebrate the golden jubilee of theFederation of Australia. The entry by the Austrian-born conductorHenry Krips (conductor)Henry Krips, "This Land of Mine", won the competition but it was decided to make no change to the status quo.Lachlan Cranswick's Personal Homepage

Until 1974 "God Save the Queen" was Australia's national anthem. In 1973 theGough WhitlamWhitlamgovernment decided that the country needed an anthem that could represent Australia with "distinction" and started a competition to find one. TheAustralia Council for the Artsorganised the contest, which was dubbed the "Australian National Anthem Quest". The contest was held in two stages, the first seeking lyrics and the second music, each having anAustralian dollarA$5,000 prize for the winning entry. On the recommendation of the Council for the Arts, none of the new entries were felt worthy enough, so the contest ended with the suggestions for "Advance Australia Fair", "Waltzing Matilda" and "Song of Australia".cite webhttp://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/symbols/anthem.cfm#historyAustralian National Anthem – HistoryAustralian Government10 July 20071 November 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20071109134834/http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/symbols/anthem.cfm#dvd_cd9 November 2007no

In 1974 the Whitlam government then performed a nationwide opinion survey to determine the song to be sung on occasions of national significance. Conducted through theAustralian Bureau of Statistics, it polled 60,000 people nationally. "Advance Australia Fair" was chosen and was enshrined as the national song, to be used on all occasions excepting those of a specifically regal nature. A spokesman for the Prime Minister Gough Whitlam stated that the Government regarded the tune primarily as the national anthem. During theAustralian federal election, 19751975 election campaignfollowing the1975 Australian constitutional crisisdismissal of Whitlam by Sir John Kerr, it was proposed byDavid Combethat the song be played at the start of the Labor Party's official campaign launch on 24 November 1975 at Festival Hall, Melbourne. Whitlam's speechwriterGraham Freudenbergrejected this idea, on two grounds, one of which was that the status of the anthem was still tentative.Graham Freudenberg, "We've been sacked",The Sunday Age, 6 November 2005, p. 13

In January 1976 theMalcolm FraserFrasergovernment reinstated "God Save the Queen" for royal, vice-regal, defence andloyal toastoccasions as well as making plans to conduct a national poll to find a song for use on ceremonial occasions when it was desired to mark a separate Australian identity. This was conducted as aAustralian plebiscite, 1977 (National Song)plebiscite to choose the National Song, held as an optional additional question in theAustralian referendum, 19771977 referendumon various issues. "Advance Australia Fair" received 43.29% of the vote, defeating the three alternatives, "Waltzing Matilda" (28.28%), "Song of Australia" (9.65%) and the existing national anthem, "God Save the Queen" (18.78%).cite webhttp://www.aph.gov.au/library/elect/referend/pleb.htmPlebiscite results: National Song Poll[[Parliament of Australia]]30 June 200213 February 2008http://web.archive.org/web/20080205110200/http://www.aph.gov.au/library/elect/referend/pleb.htm5 February 2008

"Advance Australia Fair", with modified lyrics from the original (see#Development of lyricsdevelopment of lyrics), was adopted as the Australian national anthem on 19 April 1984 by a proclamation by theGovernor-General of AustraliaGovernor-General,Ninian StephenSir Ninian Stephen,cite webhttp://www.aph.gov.au/library/handbook/national_symbols/index.htmParliamentary Handbook of the Commonwealth of Australia – National Symbols[[Parliament of Australia]]21 September 20051 November 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20070830052800/http://www.aph.gov.au/library/handbook/national_symbols/index.htm30 August 2007(proclamation by Governor-General dated 19 April 1984)on a recommendation by theAustralian Labor PartyLaborgovernment ofBob Hawke. "God Save the Queen", now known as theroyal anthem, continues to be played alongside the Australian national anthem at public engagements in Australia that are attended byElizabeth IIthe Queenor members of the Royal Family.

article.heading: Copyright
article.paragraph: Even though anycopyrightof Peter Dodds McCormick's original lyrics has expired, as he died in 1916, the Commonwealth of Australia claims copyright on the official lyrics and particular arrangements of music. Non-commercial use of the anthem is permitted without case-by-case permission, but the Commonwealth government requires permission for commercial use.cite webhttp://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/symbols/anthem.cfm#commercialAustralian National Anthem – Commercial useAustralian Government10 July 20071 November 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20071109134834/http://www.itsanhonour.gov.au/symbols/anthem.cfm#dvd_cd9 November 2007no
article.heading: Orchestral version
article.paragraph: The wordless orchestral version of "Advance Australia Fair" that is now regularly played for Australian victories at international sporting medal ceremonies, and at the openings of major domestic sporting, cultural and community events, is byTommy Tycho, an immigrant from Hungary. It was first commissioned by ABC Records in 1984 and then televised by Channel 10 in 1986 in their Australia Day Broadcast, featuringJulie Anthony (singer)Julie Anthonyas the soloist.Tommy TychoArranger
article.heading: Development of lyrics
article.paragraph: Since the original lyrics were written in 1879, there have been several changes, in some cases with the intent of increasing the anthem's inclusiveness and gender neutrality. Some of these were minor while others have significantly changed the song. The original song was four verses long. For its adoption as the national anthem, the song was cut from four verses to two. The first verse was kept largely as the 1879 original, except for the change in the first line from "Australia's sonslet us rejoice" to "Australians alllet us rejoice".The second, third and fourth verses of the original were dropped, in favour of a modified version of the new third verse which was sung atFederation of AustraliaFederationin 1901.cite webhttp://nla.gov.au/nla.mus-an6397822Digital Collections – Advance Australia Fair (1901–1919)[[National Library of Australia]]3 May 2008
The original lyrics published in 1879 were as follows:cite webhttp://www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?piDigital Collections – Advance Australia Fair (1879)[[National Library of Australia]]1 November 2007

article.heading: Criticism
article.paragraph: Both the lyrics and melody of the official anthem have been criticised in some quarters as being dull and unendearing to the Australian people. ANational Party of AustraliaNational Partysenator,Sandy Macdonald, said in 2001 that "Advance Australia Fair" is so boring that the nation risks singing itself to sleep, with boring music and words impossible to understand.cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xmlCall to scrap Australia's 'dull' anthemBarbie Dutter[[The Daily Telegraph]]27 June 200120 December 2007A parliamentary colleague,Peter Slipper, said that Australia should consider another anthem.cite webhttp://www.abc.net.au/news/politics/2001/06/item20010621121726_1.htmSenator reignites debate over national anthem[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]21 June 200120 December 2007

Specific criticism is also directed at the fourth line of lyrics, "our home is girt by sea", for its use of theArchaismarchaicword "wikt:girtgirt" to acknowledge the fact that Australia is an island.Cite newsCampbellDavidTime girt went down the gurglerHerald Sun22 April 2008http://www.heraldsun.com.au/opinion/time-girt-went-down-the-gurgler/story-e6frfifo-111111612349819 April 2011The current version of the anthem has a mix of old and new language, rather than having one style of language consistently throughout. Criticism has come from various people, includingAustralian Labor PartypoliticianCraig Emerson,Cite newsAdvance Australia Fair strikes a sour noteThe Australian2 January 2001http://www.news.com.au/common/story_page/0,4057,1570357%5E1683,00.html20 December 2007yeshttps://web.archive.org/20050723184750/http://www.news.com.au/common/story_page/0,4057,1570357%5E1683,00.html23 July 2005but others, including former Labor leaderKim Beazley, have defended it.cite webhttp://www.alp.org.au/media/0601/kbmcact210601.htmlKim Beazley – Doorstop Interview (transcript)[[Australian Labor Party]]21 June 200120 December 2007http://web.archive.org/web/20010718044509/http://www.alp.org.au/media/0601/kbmcact210601.html18 July 2001
article.heading: Alternative Christian verse
article.paragraph: A Christian movement, Awakening, in the 1990s substituted an alternative second verse naming Christ and promoting Christian values.cite webhttp://www.awakening.org.au/media/2k0606lost.htmLost verse puts Christ into the National Anthemhttp://web.archive.org/web/20001027091035/http://www.awakening.org.au/media/2k0606lost.htm27 October 20006 June 200026 January 2011An archived claim that the verse was sung in the 1930s at Smithton, Tasmania, is unsubstantiated and has been withdrawn from the original website. It was sung during the GlobalMarch for Jesusin 1998and again atWorld Youth Day 2008with the qualification "This is not the official verse, but a Catholic adaptation of the Australian National Anthem."Cite webEvans Felicity 'New' anthem verse raises inclusive questions SBS News 18 July 2008 http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/552112/-39-New-39-anthem-verse-raises-inclusive-questions 27 October 2009

The version was later controversially adopted by some Christian private schools for singing as a hymn at internal assemblies.Hiatt B. "Schools put God in our anthem"The West Australian23 September 2011, pp 1, 3.Online versionThe substituted verse did not appear in the 1879 publication of Peter Dodds McCormicks original work. The office of the Prime Minister at the time,Julia Gillard, said that, under national protocols, the anthem should not be modified and alternative words should not be used.
